DEUBEN HERMAN would inform Il the public that he has opened Shop in Litchfeld, few rods east of the Meeting house at the Stand lately occupied by I. Bunce Esq. where he will attend to the business of Clock and Watch repairing, and Silver Smith, and keeps on hand an assortment of such ar ticles as are usually called for in his line, as low as can be bought elsewhere, among which are Silver Spectacles, Spoons, Jewelry, Sc. also few first rate Brass eight day Clocks. He solicits share of the public patronage.

 As a DENTIST he will set teeth in the best manner for those who may favour him with their custom.-Cash paid for old Silver.

 Litchfield, May 30, I827.% 6w5O

 Present F. WOLCOTT, Esq. Judge. UPON the petition of William c. Abernethy and Elisha Smith, Guardians Sophia D. Hoadiy and Lu- ther Hoadly, minors, of Harwnton in said District showing to this Court that said Minors own the inter- est hereinafter mentioned, in the following described real estate, situate in the town of Winchester the in terest of said Minors in the whole ofsad being subject to the incumbrance of the life estate of their mother, Sophia Abernethy, Hate Sophia Hoady) in the one undivided third part thereof, viz:

 About three fourths of an acre of land lying the East Branch ofStill River, about half mile north of Wnsted Meeting House, in said town of Winchester, with dwelling house and shed standing thereon.

 Aso sixtyseven rods of land lying east ofthe piece above described.

 A!so the one undivided half of seven acres of land owned in common with Riley Whiting, lying on the East branch of said Still Rver and north of the high way leading to Walling's hill.

 Also, one undivided half of Grist Mill and the one undivided half of seven eghts of the mill privilege and the one undivided half of small mill house, with about half of an acre of land on which said mill and mill house stand. 4

 Also. the one halfof Clock Shop, and the one half ofseven eghts of the water privilege ofthe same, with the one half of small piece of land on which said shop stands and that which adjoins the same which has heretofore been occupied as a lumber yard.

 Also, the undivided third part of fifteen acres of land lying in said Winchester, on the East Bank of said Stin River, bounded north on Halsey Burr and Riley Whiting g:--praying for liberty to sell the same, as her petition on file, dated May 4, 1927.

 Whereupon this Court doth order that said petition be continued to the second Monday in September next at ten o'clock A. M then be heard before this Court at the Probate Office in Litchfeld in sad Dis rict and that notice of the pendancy of said petition be given by publishing this order in newspaperprin- ted in said Ltchfeld three weeks successvey least six weeks before said second Monday in September next. A true Copy of Record.

 FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Judge.

THE Hon. Court of Probate for the District of Litch6eld hath assigned Tuesday the 18th day ot ln- stant July at ten o'clock in the orenoon at the Pro- bate Office in Litchfeld for the examination and set clement of the administration account of the subscrl- ber Executor of :he last will and testament of Joseph Mansfield, late of said Ltchfeld, deceased, at which time and place all persons interested in said Estate will they see cause attend before said court and be heard in the premises By order of said Court

 JOHN T. MANSFIELD, Ececutor. 2 ELIHU HARRISON.

ESTRAY.

man may give that the habit ls coming over him with power. The signs he names are seven in number. of which we now copy the first. Boston Recorder

 One of the early indications of intemper- ance may be found in the associations of time and place. In the commencement of this e. vii habit there are many who drink to excess only on particular days, such as days for mil- itary exhibition, the anniversary of eur inde- pendence. the birth day of Washington, Christmas, new years day, election, and others of the like nature. When any of these holidays arrive. and they come as often al- most as saints days in the calendar. they bring with them to many the unsuitable de- sire of drinking as well as a dispensatiOn from the sin, as eficacious and quieting to the con- science, as papal indulgences.

 There are some am aware that have re- commended the multiplication of holidays and public amusementS, as a remedy for lntem- perance about as wise prescrptiOn-as the multiplying gambling houses to superscede gambling, pr the building of theatres to cor rect the evils of the stage.

 There are others who feel the desire of drinking stirred up within them by the asso- citations of place. They could go from end

  its, were there nc tavern on the road. But the very sight of these resceptacles of pil- grims awakens the desire 'iust to step in and take something." And so powerful does the association become, that many will nO more pass tavern than they would pass a fortified place with all the engines of death directed against them. There are in every city, town and village, places of resort, which in like manner as soon as the eye falls upon them creates thirst of drinking, and many who coming to market on business, ,pass near them, pay toll there as regularly as they do at the gates and sometimes both when they come in and when they go out. In cities and their suburbs, there are hundreds of shops at which a large proportion of those who bring produce stop regularly to receive the customary bey- craze.

 In every community you may observe par ticular persons who can never meet without feeling the simultaneous desire of strong drink. What can be the reason of this ! All men, when they meet are not affected thus. 1t is not uncommon for men of similar em- ployment to be drawn by association, when they meet, to the same topics of conversation: physicians, upon the concerns of their pro- fession :-politicians, upon the events of the day :-and Christians when they meet, are drawn by common interest to speak of the kingdom of God. But this is upon the principle of a common interest in these sub- iects, which has no slight hold upon the thoughts and affections. Whoever then finds himself tempted on meeting his companion or friend to say, "come and let us go and take something,' 2 or, to make it his first busi- ness to set out his decanter and glasses, ought to understand that he discloses his in- ordinate attachment to ardent spirits, and accuses his Friend of incompetence.

 Sympathy ofthe Heart.-There is curious thing with respect to the heart, showing its sympathies with the lungs. This is one of the curious experiments that have been made. If an animal be pithed,the medulla spinalis be divided high up, he dies; because the lungs want energy, and the diaphrGmatie nerve has its function abolished, and dies for want of breath. But let him be pithed and rcspira- ton kept up by mechanical means, the infa- tion kept up and life will go on. Now this is pair of bellows for drowned animals; he upon the lungs, for "when l left off blowing my bellows, (said John the heart left of it's motion; and when began again to blow in-

  action, at first feebly, but after little. more strongly I use the words exactly as Mir. Hunter uttered them. Now, trust all that nonsense is completely abolished: people say the cereJrum has no influence upon the heart but I say unquestiOnably, it has great influence upon it, and quote an instance to show it: suppose timid person, or deli cate female, hears noise in the middle of the night, which she supposes either to he a ghost ora robber egad, her pulsation falls, she gets cold and is so alarmed as to be al. most dead. Suppose fellow calls another person scoundrel ;-the person so called, feels his spirit rising, his face grows red, and he takes up his fist, and knocks the other down. Now, why such person as Bichat should point to the heart as the seat of feeling. and puts his other hand upon his| head to denote that it'sthe place of thought, don't know but his head had no thought init, think, when he talked such nonsense as that. You know that pleasant feelings do 1 produce pleasant action, as Shakespeare 1 said, ' my bosom's lord sits lightly on its thrOnc;" and that uneasiness of mind has di- ] rectly the converse effect. It is therefore l certainly the effect of the cerebrum that acts ! upon these organs. wonder it had not en- tered into the wise head of some person to ar- | que that the diaphragm was not the seat of all these emotions. Shakespeare seems to me to have most sensibly felt these emotions Canst thou minister to a mind diseased ! l pinck rom the memory a rooted sorrow |
SIGNS OF INTEMPERANcE.

NOTICE.

No article of Houshold Manufactures will be enti- tied to premium unless manuatured entirely within the county.

 To entitle himself to premiums for Horticultural Productions, the person claiming must state in wri- ting, and prove to the satisfaction of the Awarding Committee, the quantity of land, and the amount of the product Ito be ascerained by measure, and must also state in writing the nature or kind of soil--he previous situation of the Iand-how tilled-thc kind and quality manure, and how and when appied--how the seed was applied, and how, and when sown, and the quantity per acre.

 The claims for premiums under this article mus, be entered with the Treasurer, MR. LEONARD Coop WIN on or before the 9th day of October next; but the evidence of actual product except aax which will be admitted till the list day of March next and Winter Wheat to the 1st day of January l829 will be admit ted at any time previous to the fst day of January next Persons intending to offer Domestic Animals, or Houshold manufactures give notice to the Treas arer, on or before the 9th day of October next re- quMeailng an entry to be made of such notice. out competition, unless such article shall be, in the pinlon ot the Awarding Committee, highly merito- rious. No Animal or article of Houshold Manufacture. winch shall have obtained premium previous ex- hlbton, wills under the same denomination be enti- tied to second premium.

 A statement of the quantity and quality of Milk giv- en by, and of the butter made from, the Mich Cows entered for premiums crediby attested will be requi- red ny the Awarding Commte.

 The examinations of Domestic Animals and Hous. hold Manufactures will commence near the Court House, at 9 A. M.

 No person but member ofthe Society, can be en- titled to premium except on Hearth Rugs, Bonnets Stockings and other articles of Domestic Manufac. tnres highly meritorious.

 All premiums not called for within three months at- ter awarded, will be forfeited to the Society.

 UTAH persons in arrears to the Society, are re- qnested 10 forward the amount to the TreasIrer

 FOR ALBANY AND HUDSON.

 Leaves Litchfeld daily Sundays excepted at o. clock in the morning, arrives at each place af ternoOn, and returns from each place in the order

 LITCHFIELD AND NEW-HAVEN. Leaves Ltchfeld for New-Haven daily Sundays excepted) at o'clock in the morning; Monday, We'd nesday and Friday, by Bethem, WOOdbury, Southbu- ry, Oxford, Humphreys-Ve, and arrives in N. Haven at P. M.; Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday, by WatertOwn, Waterbury, Salem-bridge, and Wood bridge, arrives at N. Haven at 9 P. M. and returns from N. Haven in the same order.

 LITCHFIELD AND HARTFORD.

 Leaves Litchfeld for Hartford, Tuesdays, Thurs days and Saturdays o'clock in the morning thro' HarwintOn, Burlington, Pennington and West-Hart- ford, and arrives in Hartford at o'clock P. M Re- turns from Hartford Mondays, Wednesdays and Fri days at o'clock in the morning.

 LITCHFIELD AND NORWALK.

 Leaves Ltchfeld for New-Milford, Danbury and Norwalk every Friday afternoon on arrival of the Stage from Hartford, through Bradleys-Ville, New Preston, New-Milford Brookfeld, Danbury, Reading, and Wilton, and arrives at Norwalk on Saturday at 12 o'clock at noon. Returns from Norwalk Sundays, arrives at Litchfeld Monday afternoon.

 This Line intersects the Steamboat at Norwalk and arrives in N. York same night.

 The Steamboat leaves N. Haven for N. York eve- " evening at z o'clock.

 The Steam-Boats leave Hartford for N. York Mon- days, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at Il o'clock A. M.

 For information or passage in the above Lines ap- ply to J. PARKS. Ltchfed, June II, 1897. tf52

and for the District of Litchfeld, July 2d, 1897.

 Present F. WOLCOTT, Esq. Judge. UPON the petition of William c. Abernethy and Elisha Smith, Guardians Sophia D. Hoadiy and Lu- ther Hoadly, minors, of Harwnton in said District showing to this Court that said Minors own the inter- est hereinafter mentioned, in the following described real estate, situate in the town of Winchester the in terest of said Minors in the whole ofsad being subject to the incumbrance of the life estate of their mother, Sophia Abernethy, Hate Sophia Hoady) in the one undivided third part thereof, viz:

 About three fourths of an acre of land lying the East Branch ofStill River, about half mile north of Wnsted Meeting House, in said town of Winchester, with dwelling house and shed standing thereon.

 Aso sixtyseven rods of land lying east ofthe piece above described.

 A!so the one undivided half of seven acres of land owned in common with Riley Whiting, lying on the East branch of said Still Rver and north of the high way leading to Walling's hill.

 Also, one undivided half of Grist Mill and the one undivided half of seven eghts of the mill privilege and the one undivided half of small mill house, with about half of an acre of land on which said mill and mill house stand. 4

 Also. the one halfof Clock Shop, and the one half ofseven eghts of the water privilege ofthe same, with the one half of small piece of land on which said shop stands and that which adjoins the same which has heretofore been occupied as a lumber yard.

 Also, the undivided third part of fifteen acres of land lying in said Winchester, on the East Bank of said Stin River, bounded north on Halsey Burr and Riley Whiting g:--praying for liberty to sell the same, as her petition on file, dated May 4, 1927.

 Whereupon this Court doth order that said petition be continued to the second Monday in September next at ten o'clock A. M then be heard before this Court at the Probate Office in Litchfeld in sad Dis rict and that notice of the pendancy of said petition be given by publishing this order in newspaperprin- ted in said Ltchfeld three weeks successvey least six weeks before said second Monday in September next. A true Copy of Record.

 FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Judge.

LEAVES Poughkeepsie every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, at o'clock A: M, passes through Sha- ron, and arrives at Ltch6eld the same day, where it meets the Hartford, New-Haven, and Albany sta-

 Leaves Litchfeld every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday, at 5 o'clock A. M. and arrives at Pough- keepse in time to take the Steamboat for New York or Albany.-Passengers in this line will arrive in AL bany the morning after leaving Litch6eld in time to take the morning stages for the west. .,

 The proprietors of this line having provided good coaches and horses and careful drivers and reduced the fare respectfully solicit share of public patron- age. e

full articles.headline: SIGNS OF INTEMPERANcE.
full articles.article:
man may give that the habit ls coming over him with power. The signs he names are seven in number. of which we now copy the first. Boston Recorder

 One of the early indications of intemper- ance may be found in the associations of time and place. In the commencement of this e. vii habit there are many who drink to excess only on particular days, such as days for mil- itary exhibition, the anniversary of eur inde- pendence. the birth day of Washington, Christmas, new years day, election, and others of the like nature. When any of these holidays arrive. and they come as often al- most as saints days in the calendar. they bring with them to many the unsuitable de- sire of drinking as well as a dispensatiOn from the sin, as eficacious and quieting to the con- science, as papal indulgences.

 There are some am aware that have re- commended the multiplication of holidays and public amusementS, as a remedy for lntem- perance about as wise prescrptiOn-as the multiplying gambling houses to superscede gambling, pr the building of theatres to cor rect the evils of the stage.

 There are others who feel the desire of drinking stirred up within them by the asso- citations of place. They could go from end

  its, were there nc tavern on the road. But the very sight of these resceptacles of pil- grims awakens the desire 'iust to step in and take something." And so powerful does the association become, that many will nO more pass tavern than they would pass a fortified place with all the engines of death directed against them. There are in every city, town and village, places of resort, which in like manner as soon as the eye falls upon them creates thirst of drinking, and many who coming to market on business, ,pass near them, pay toll there as regularly as they do at the gates and sometimes both when they come in and when they go out. In cities and their suburbs, there are hundreds of shops at which a large proportion of those who bring produce stop regularly to receive the customary bey- craze.

 In every community you may observe par ticular persons who can never meet without feeling the simultaneous desire of strong drink. What can be the reason of this ! All men, when they meet are not affected thus. 1t is not uncommon for men of similar em- ployment to be drawn by association, when they meet, to the same topics of conversation: physicians, upon the concerns of their pro- fession :-politicians, upon the events of the day :-and Christians when they meet, are drawn by common interest to speak of the kingdom of God. But this is upon the principle of a common interest in these sub- iects, which has no slight hold upon the thoughts and affections. Whoever then finds himself tempted on meeting his companion or friend to say, "come and let us go and take something,' 2 or, to make it his first busi- ness to set out his decanter and glasses, ought to understand that he discloses his in- ordinate attachment to ardent spirits, and accuses his Friend of incompetence.

 Sympathy ofthe Heart.-There is curious thing with respect to the heart, showing its sympathies with the lungs. This is one of the curious experiments that have been made. If an animal be pithed,the medulla spinalis be divided high up, he dies; because the lungs want energy, and the diaphrGmatie nerve has its function abolished, and dies for want of breath. But let him be pithed and rcspira- ton kept up by mechanical means, the infa- tion kept up and life will go on. Now this is pair of bellows for drowned animals; he upon the lungs, for "when l left off blowing my bellows, (said John the heart left of it's motion; and when began again to blow in-

  action, at first feebly, but after little. more strongly I use the words exactly as Mir. Hunter uttered them. Now, trust all that nonsense is completely abolished: people say the cereJrum has no influence upon the heart but I say unquestiOnably, it has great influence upon it, and quote an instance to show it: suppose timid person, or deli cate female, hears noise in the middle of the night, which she supposes either to he a ghost ora robber egad, her pulsation falls, she gets cold and is so alarmed as to be al. most dead. Suppose fellow calls another person scoundrel ;-the person so called, feels his spirit rising, his face grows red, and he takes up his fist, and knocks the other down. Now, why such person as Bichat should point to the heart as the seat of feeling. and puts his other hand upon his| head to denote that it'sthe place of thought, don't know but his head had no thought init, think, when he talked such nonsense as that. You know that pleasant feelings do 1 produce pleasant action, as Shakespeare 1 said, ' my bosom's lord sits lightly on its thrOnc;" and that uneasiness of mind has di- ] rectly the converse effect. It is therefore l certainly the effect of the cerebrum that acts ! upon these organs. wonder it had not en- tered into the wise head of some person to ar- | que that the diaphragm was not the seat of all these emotions. Shakespeare seems to me to have most sensibly felt these emotions Canst thou minister to a mind diseased ! l pinck rom the memory a rooted sorrow |

No article of Houshold Manufactures will be enti- tied to premium unless manuatured entirely within the county.

 To entitle himself to premiums for Horticultural Productions, the person claiming must state in wri- ting, and prove to the satisfaction of the Awarding Committee, the quantity of land, and the amount of the product Ito be ascerained by measure, and must also state in writing the nature or kind of soil--he previous situation of the Iand-how tilled-thc kind and quality manure, and how and when appied--how the seed was applied, and how, and when sown, and the quantity per acre.

 The claims for premiums under this article mus, be entered with the Treasurer, MR. LEONARD Coop WIN on or before the 9th day of October next; but the evidence of actual product except aax which will be admitted till the list day of March next and Winter Wheat to the 1st day of January l829 will be admit ted at any time previous to the fst day of January next Persons intending to offer Domestic Animals, or Houshold manufactures give notice to the Treas arer, on or before the 9th day of October next re- quMeailng an entry to be made of such notice. out competition, unless such article shall be, in the pinlon ot the Awarding Committee, highly merito- rious. No Animal or article of Houshold Manufacture. winch shall have obtained premium previous ex- hlbton, wills under the same denomination be enti- tied to second premium.

 A statement of the quantity and quality of Milk giv- en by, and of the butter made from, the Mich Cows entered for premiums crediby attested will be requi- red ny the Awarding Commte.

 The examinations of Domestic Animals and Hous. hold Manufactures will commence near the Court House, at 9 A. M.

 No person but member ofthe Society, can be en- titled to premium except on Hearth Rugs, Bonnets Stockings and other articles of Domestic Manufac. tnres highly meritorious.

 All premiums not called for within three months at- ter awarded, will be forfeited to the Society.

 UTAH persons in arrears to the Society, are re- qnested 10 forward the amount to the TreasIrer

 GT An GRAFTON will be delivered on the oc. casion. Per order, S. P. BOLLES, Rec. Sec.

 LOaninC Lines. ..
full articles.article:
LOsoing LGnes.

 FOR ALBANY AND HUDSON.

 Leaves Litchfeld daily Sundays excepted at o. clock in the morning, arrives at each place af ternoOn, and returns from each place in the order

 LITCHFIELD AND NEW-HAVEN. Leaves Ltchfeld for New-Haven daily Sundays excepted) at o'clock in the morning; Monday, We'd nesday and Friday, by Bethem, WOOdbury, Southbu- ry, Oxford, Humphreys-Ve, and arrives in N. Haven at P. M.; Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday, by WatertOwn, Waterbury, Salem-bridge, and Wood bridge, arrives at N. Haven at 9 P. M. and returns from N. Haven in the same order.

 LITCHFIELD AND HARTFORD.

 Leaves Litchfeld for Hartford, Tuesdays, Thurs days and Saturdays o'clock in the morning thro' HarwintOn, Burlington, Pennington and West-Hart- ford, and arrives in Hartford at o'clock P. M Re- turns from Hartford Mondays, Wednesdays and Fri days at o'clock in the morning.

 LITCHFIELD AND NORWALK.

 Leaves Ltchfeld for New-Milford, Danbury and Norwalk every Friday afternoon on arrival of the Stage from Hartford, through Bradleys-Ville, New Preston, New-Milford Brookfeld, Danbury, Reading, and Wilton, and arrives at Norwalk on Saturday at 12 o'clock at noon. Returns from Norwalk Sundays, arrives at Litchfeld Monday afternoon.

 This Line intersects the Steamboat at Norwalk and arrives in N. York same night.

 The Steamboat leaves N. Haven for N. York eve- " evening at z o'clock.

 The Steam-Boats leave Hartford for N. York Mon- days, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at Il o'clock A. M.

 For information or passage in the above Lines ap- ply to J. PARKS. Ltchfed, June II, 1897. tf52
